history.content: If i were you I'd double CS and Econ. CS and DS are too similar/too much overlap for the double major to really mean anything, unless you want a double major just for the sake of having a double major.

children.subject:
^ I am going to disagree with Anon Calc here. I am doubling in CS and DS rn and honestly, the overlap can be very small if you want it to. Just because they both use computers doesn't mean they are similar. It is like saying soccer and basketball are similar because they both involve balls. If you are interested in DS you would very likely to take courses that focus on a wide range of mathematic topics like stats and probability, calculus, linear algebra and optimization, and many others that I am too scared to take. In contrast for CS you barely need any math, and you would spend a lot of time understanding design choices ranging from data structures and algorithms to databases and network protocols, and you would dive a lot deeper into the lower stacks of computers (61c already takes you a long way down), and DS you don't really need to know how the code runs and can survive most courses knowing the bare minimum of python.  

The only problem I see is that if your goal is to find a job rather than grad school the double major probably won't help you very much. For one thing, data science is such a new major that many companies don't have that listed as one of the majors. Also, the two majors lead toward two quite different career paths, so it is more of a way of keeping more options open than making you more competitive for either position. I am not planning for grad school so I don't know how much the double major would benefit, but at least I think keeping options open for grad school is more important as that's a greater commitment than finding a job.
Probably SWE, and I intend to work in industry after undergrad then go back and get a masters degree, most likely an MBA

I don’t have a ton of experience but I’m considering to double with DS too mainly because of how few classes it adds for me after classes I already intended to take but in that case I don’t think it adds a lot of benefit for what you’d be doing. Probably makes sense to do if it’s not too much more from what you have done but if it adds a lot of stress I don’t think it’s too worth jt
It depends on what you want to do in the future. What kind of job are you targeting: SWE, Data Scientist, ML engineer etc? Do you also intend to go to grad school?

history.content: Am I playing myself by doubling in DS? My logic is that I only need to take a few classes like 4 to get the major as I was already pursuing the minor. My domain emphasis is Econ, and that's the bulk of the classes I need for the ds major along with the upper div probability req, so should I drop this and try to put this time into something else such as other CS classes I want to take, or stick with it. I'm a junior by the way. What I will say is without the DS major my grades would probably be slightly better
history.subject: CS + DS Major
